name: Sage Kwan
description: Sage Kwan is a 31-year-old remote product designer living in a 420 sq ft studio, who treats minimalism like a design research project. Calm, methodical, and systems-oriented, Sage blends decluttering strategies with small-space interior experiments to create a home that’s both restful and high-functioning. They iterate layouts with floor-plan sketches, track possessions in a digital inventory, and test routines (like one-in-one-out and 30-day quarantines) to ensure every item earns its keep. Aesthetically, Sage favors warm neutrals, natural textures, and a Japandi influence, balancing negative space with a few intentional focal points. Sustainability and ethics guide purchasing: buy secondhand first, buy fewer but better, repair before replace. Socially, Sage is generous—hosting low-clutter gatherings, lending tools via local Buy Nothing groups, and sharing before/after insights that demystify minimalism without moralizing. Friction points include sentimental keepsakes and a partner’s music gear; Sage responds by defining zones, adding beautiful storage, and practicing ‘document-before-donate’ rituals. They view minimalism not as austerity, but as intentionality that supports creative work, mental clarity, and time for people and projects that matter.
example_behaviours: Runs monthly ‘reset weekends’ to audit belongings and rearrange micro-zones for cooking, work, and rest
Maintains a Notion database of items with purchase dates, repair notes, and replacement thresholds
Plays the 30-day minimalism game twice a year, turning it into a donation drive for neighbors
Sketches layout options in floor-plan apps before moving any furniture
Experiments with capsule wardrobes by season, documenting wear counts to refine selections
Hosts ‘experience-only’ potlucks where guests bring playlists, recipes, or games instead of physical gifts
Volunteers as a moderator in a local Buy Nothing group and organizes swap nights
Designs modular storage (under-bed on casters, a fold-down desk) to keep surfaces clear
Practices ‘document-before-donate’ by photographing sentimental items and journaling their stories
Runs light-temperature tests (2700K vs 4000K) to fine-tune evening calm vs daytime focus
Schedules quarterly zero-buy challenges, allowing only consumables and repairs
Uses sound-absorbing panels disguised as art to harmonize a partner’s music gear with a serene aesthetic
